member.name: T:StockTicker.HttpRoute
member.summary: Route for ASP.NET Web API applications

member.name: T:StockTicker.Logging.CombiningTarget
member.summary: A logger to use for combining a number of other loggers

Creates the target with a custom output template. The default `outputTemplate` is `[{timestampLocal:HH:mm:ss} {level}] {message}{exceptions}`. Available template fields are: `timestamp`, `timestampUtc`, `level`, `source`, `newline`, `tab`, `message`, `exceptions`. Any misspelled or otheriwese invalid property names will be treated as `LiterateToken.MissingTemplateField`.

member.name: T:StockTicker.Logging.LiterateConsoleTarget
member.summary: Logs a line in a format that is great for human consumption, using console colours to enhance readability. Sample: [10:30:49 INF] User "AdamC" began the "checkout" process with 100 cart items

member.name: P:StockTicker.Logging.LoggingConfig.consoleSemaphore
member.summary: When composing apps from the outside-in (rather than having a unified framework with static/global config) with libraries (again, rather than a unified framework) like is best-practice, there's not necessarily a way to coordinate around the STDOUT and STDERR streams between different libraries running things on different threads. Use Logary's adapter to replace this semaphore with a global semaphore.

member.name: P:StockTicker.Logging.LoggingConfig.getLogger
member.summary: The `getLogger` function returns a logger that directly can be logged to.

member.name: P:StockTicker.Logging.LoggingConfig.timestamp
member.summary: The `timestamp` function should preferably be monotonic and not 'jumpy' or take much time to call.

member.name: M:StockTicker.Logging.Logger.logWithAck(StockTicker.Logging.LogLevel,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{StockTicker.Logging.LogLevel,StockTicker.Logging.Message})
member.summary:
Logs with the specified log level with backpressure via the logging library's buffers *and* ACK/flush to the underlying message targets.
Calls to this function will block the caller only while executing the callback (if the level is active).
The returned async value will yield when the message has been flushed to the underlying message targets.
You need to start the (cold) async value for the logging to happen.
You should not do blocking/heavy operations in the callback.

member.name: M:StockTicker.Logging.Logger.log(StockTicker.Logging.LogLevel,Microsoft.FSharp.Core.FSharpFunc{StockTicker.Logging.LogLevel,StockTicker.Logging.Message})
member.summary:
Logs with the specified log level with backpressure via the logging library's buffers.
Calls to this function will block the caller only while executing the callback (if the level is active).
The returned async value will yield when the message has been added to the buffers of the logging library.
You need to start the (cold) async value for the logging to happen.
You should not do blocking/heavy operations in the callback.

member.summary: The 'path' or 'name' of this data point. Do not confuse template in (Event template) = message.value

member.name: P:StockTicker.Logging.Message.utcTicks
member.summary: Gets the ticks for UTC since 0001-01-01 00:00:00 for this message. You can pass this value into a DateTimeOffset c'tor

member.name: P:StockTicker.Logging.Message.README
member.summary: If you're looking for how to transform the Message's fields, then use the module methods rather than instance methods, since you'll be creating new values rather than changing an existing value.

member.name: T:StockTicker.Logging.Message
member.summary: This is record that is logged. It's capable of representing both metrics (gauges) and events. See https://github.com/logary/logary for details.

member.name: T:StockTicker.Logging.EpochNanoSeconds
member.summary: The # of nanoseconds after 1970-01-01 00:00:00.

member.name: T:StockTicker.Logging.PointValue.Gauge
member.summary: This is as value for a metric, with a unit attached. The unit can be something like Seconds or Hz.

member.name: T:StockTicker.Logging.PointValue.Event
member.summary: An event is what it sounds like; something occurred and needs to be logged. Its field is named 'template' because it should not be interpolated with values; instead these values should be put in the 'fields' field of the Message.

member.name: T:StockTicker.Logging.PointValue
member.summary: Represents a logged value; either a Gauge or an Event.

member.name: T:StockTicker.Logging.LogLevel.Fatal
member.summary: The log message denotes a fatal error which cannot be recovered from. The service should be shut down. Human corrective action is needed.

member.name: T:StockTicker.Logging.LogLevel.Error
member.summary: The log message is at an error level, meaning an unhandled exception occurred at a location where it is deemed important to keeping the service running. A human should take corrective action.

member.name: T:StockTicker.Logging.LogLevel.Warn
member.summary: The log message is a warning; e.g. there was an unhandled exception or an even occurred which was unexpected. Sometimes human corrective action is needed.

member.name: T:StockTicker.Logging.LogLevel.Info
member.summary: The log message is informational; e.g. the service started, stopped or some important business event occurred.

member.name: T:StockTicker.Logging.LogLevel.Debug
member.summary: The log message is at a default level, debug level. Useful for shipping to infrastructure that further processes it, but not so useful for human inspection in its raw format, except during development.

member.name: T:StockTicker.Logging.LogLevel.Verbose
member.summary: The log message is not that important; can be used for intricate debugging.

member.summary:
Create a new target. Prefer `Log.create` in your own libraries, or let the composing app replace your target instance through your configuration.
Will log to console (colourised) by default, and also to the output window in your IDE if you specify a level below Info.

member.name: T:StockTicker.Logging.Global.Flyweight
member.summary: The flyweight just references the current configuration. If you want multiple per-process logging setups, then don't use the static methods, but instead pass a Logger instance around, setting the name field of the Message value you pass into the logger.

member.name: M:StockTicker.Logging.LiterateFormatting.tokeniserForOutputTemplate(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a `LiterateTokeniser` function which can be passed to the `LiterateConsoleTarget` constructor in order to customise how each log message is rendered. The default template would be: `[{timestampLocal:HH:mm:ss} {level}] {message}{newline}{exceptions}`. Available template fields are: `timestamp`, `timestampUtc`, `level`, `source`, `newline`, `tab`, `message`, `exceptions`. Any misspelled or otheriwese invalid property names will be treated as `LiterateToken.MissingTemplateField`.

member.name: M:StockTicker.Logging.LoggerEx.Logger.logSimple(StockTicker.Logging.Logger,StockTicker.Logging.Message)
member.summary:
Log a message, but don't synchronously wait for the message to be placed inside the logging library's buffers. Instead the message will be added to the logging library's buffers asynchronously (with respect to the caller) with a timeout of 5 seconds, and will then be dropped.
This is the way we avoid the unbounded buffer problem.
If you have dropped messages, they will be logged to STDERR. You should load- test your app to ensure that your targets can send at a rate high enough without dropping messages.
It's recommended to have alerting on STDERR.
